name: Guru Amar Das Ji
excerpt: Guru Amar Das Ji became the third Sikh Guru in 1552 at the age of 73. Revered for his humility, he greatly expanded Sikhism through the Manji system, established the first Sikh pilgrimage center at Goindwal, championed social reforms like gender and caste equality, and composed many hymns including Anand Sahib. His leadership solidified Sikh institutions, elevated the practice of langar, and advanced the Sikh faith’s message of service, inclusion, and spiritual discipline.

quickStats.label: Major Contributions
quickStats.value: Manji system, Goindwal Baoli, Anand Sahib, social reforms

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Amar Das was born on 5 May 1479 in Basarke, Punjab. Raised in a devout Hindu family, he was deeply religious and became a follower of Vaishnavism early in life. Married to Mata Mansa Devi, he had two sons, Mohan and Mohri, and two daughters, Dani and Bhani.

biographySections.label: Meeting Guru Angad and Spiritual Transformation
biographySections.value: In his early 60s, Amar Das met Guru Angad Dev Ji, having been inspired by the hymns recited by Bibi Amro (Guru Angad’s daughter). Drawn by Guru Angad’s teachings, he devoted himself to humble service (seva), becoming a symbol of selfless devotion.

biographySections.label: Appointment as Guru
biographySections.value: Recognizing his devotion and integrity, Guru Angad Dev Ji appointed Amar Das as the third Sikh Guru in 1552, at age 73, superseding his own sons.

biographySections.label: Spiritual and Social Reforms
biographySections.value: Guru Amar Das Ji worked to end social disparities by abolishing practices such as sati and purdah, promoting widow remarriage, and opposing the caste system. He established the Sikh principle of Langar (community kitchen) as compulsory for all visitors, including Emperor Akbar.

biographySections.label: The Manji System and Expansion of Sikhism
biographySections.value: To organize and spread Sikh teachings, he created the Manji system, dividing the Sikh community into 22 regions, each led by a representative preacher. He also appointed women to positions of spiritual leadership.

biographySections.label: Goindwal Baoli and Pilgrimage
biographySections.value: Guru Amar Das Ji founded the town of Goindwal Sahib and built Baoli Sahib, an 84-step well that became Sikhism’s first major pilgrimage site. He instituted the practice of visiting Goindwal for festivals and gatherings.

biographySections.label: Compositions and Literary Legacy
biographySections.value: He composed 907 hymns, including the Anand Sahib, emphasizing bliss through devotional worship, ethical living, and remembrance of God. His bani forms a major portion of the Guru Granth Sahib.

biographySections.label: Final Years and Succession
biographySections.value: Spending his last years at Goindwal in devotional service, Guru Amar Das Ji appointed his son-in-law Bhai Jetha (Guru Ram Das Ji) as his successor, continuing the merit-based tradition of Guruship.

spiritualLegacy.description: Guru Amar Das Ji’s legacy is defined by social equality and spiritual discipline. He reinforced ‘seva’ (service) as a spiritual path and expanded Sikh practice with new institutions and liturgical compositions.
keyContributions: Introduced the Manji and Piri system for spiritual administration and women’s leadership
Solidified regular Sikh festivals (Baisakhi, Diwali) and pilgrimages
Composed Anand Sahib and numerous hymns
Expanded Langar and eliminated social barriers in Sikh worship

modernRelevance.description: Guru Amar Das Ji’s teachings on equality, dignity of women, and universal service remain pillars of Sikh faith and social work globally.
contemporaryImpact: Manji system model influences Sikh missions and community structure
Langar as a symbol of equality, now global in Sikh Gurdwaras
Women’s empowerment and leadership in Sikh institutions
Anand Sahib integral to all major Sikh ceremonies

achievements.title: Established Manji System
achievements.description: Divided the Sikh sphere into 22 manjis and appointed preachers, including women, to spread Sikh teaching.

achievements.title: Abolished Sati and Promoted Widow Remarriage
achievements.description: Issued edicts abolishing the practice of sati and supported widow remarriage.

achievements.title: Built Baoli Sahib at Goindwal
achievements.description: Constructed an 84-step stepwell at Goindwal, establishing the first Sikh pilgrimage center.

achievements.title: Composed Anand Sahib
achievements.description: Authored the Anand Sahib and 907 hymns included in Guru Granth Sahib.

achievements.title: Strengthened Langar Institution
achievements.description: Made Langar compulsory and a symbol of casteless equality in Sikhism.

quotes.translation: As one serves, so does one become.
quotes.context: On the importance of selfless service (seva)
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib), Ang 474

quotes.original: ਸਭੁ ਕੋ ਵਟਾ ਵੇਖਿਆ ਆਪੇ ਵਡਿਆਈ ਦੇਇ ॥
quotes.transliteration: Sabh ko vaḍā vekhiā āpe vaḍiāī dei.
quotes.translation: Everyone seeks greatness, but only the Divine bestows it.
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib), Ang 1331

quotes.translation: The world is asleep, only a rare one reflects.
quotes.source: ਗੁਰੂ ਗ੍ਰੰਥ ਸਾਹਿਬ (Guru Granth Sahib), Ang 919

timeline.event: Birth of Guru Amar Das Ji in Basarke, Punjab
Becomes disciple of Guru Angad Dev Ji
Appointed as the 3rd Sikh Guru at age 73
Establishes Goindwal and constructs Baoli Sahib
Guru Amar Das Ji passes away at Goindwal Sahib

relatedPersonalities.name: Bibi Bhani Ji
relatedPersonalities.relation: Daughter, mother of Guru Arjan Dev Ji

historicalContext.politicalSituation: Indian subcontinent under early Mughal rule (Babur, Humayun, Akbar); Punjab fragmented with rising Mughal authority.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Rigid caste system, gender inequality, religious diversity with entrenched ritualism. Socio-religious reform movements gaining ground.
historicalContext.significance: Guru Amar Das Ji’s institution-building, gender and caste reforms, and spiritual teachings helped shape Sikhism into a distinct faith and unified movement.

references: Guru Amar Das: Third Sikh Guru by Surjit Singh Gandhi
